a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol1 book 4
Indeed, Allah the Exalted has said: "The competition for increase [at-takathur] has distracted you." (102:1) And the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The love of wealth [al-mal] and status [ash-sharaf] cause hypocrisy [nifaq] to grow in the heart [qalb] just as water causes plants to grow." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Two ravenous wolves let loose among a flock of sheep do not cause more corruption in it than the love of status [ash-sharaf], wealth [al-mal], and prestige [al-jah] cause in the religion [din] of a Muslim man." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The wealthy [al-mukthirun] are ruined, except for those who say with their wealth in the path of Allah like this and like this—and few are they." And it was said: "O Messenger of Allah, who are the worst of your community?" He said: "The wealthy [al-aghniya']." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "There will come after you a people who eat the choicest foods of the world [ad-dunya] and its varieties, ride the finest horses and their varieties, marry the most beautiful women and their varieties, and wear the finest clothes and their varieties. Their bellies are not satisfied with little, and their souls [anfus] are not content with much. They are devoted to the world [ad-dunya], going to it in the morning and returning to it in the evening. They have taken it as a god besides their God and a lord besides their Lord. They end at its command and follow its desires. So, a firm resolve from Muhammad, son of Abdullah, to those of your descendants and successors who reach that time: do not greet them with peace, do not visit their sick, do not follow their funeral processions, and do not honor their elders. For whoever does that has indeed aided in the destruction of Islam." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "Leave the world [ad-dunya] for its people. Whoever takes from the world [ad-dunya] more than what suffices him takes his own destruction while he is unaware." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The son of Adam says, 'My wealth [mali], my wealth [mali]!' But do you have anything of your wealth [mal] except what you ate and thus consumed, or wore and thus wore out, or gave in charity and thus forwarded?" And a man said: "O Messenger of Allah, why do I not love death?" He said: "Do you have wealth [mal]?" The man said: "Yes, O Messenger of Allah." He said: "Send your wealth [mal] forward, for the heart [qalb] of the believer is with his wealth [mal]. If he sends it forward, he loves to join it. If he leaves it behind, he loves to remain with it." And he, peace and blessings be upon him, said: "The companions of the son of Adam are three. One follows him until his soul [ruh] is taken, the second follows him to his grave, and the third follows him to the gathering place [al-mahshar]. The one who follows him until his soul [ruh] is taken is his wealth [maluhu]. The one who follows him to his grave is his family [ahluhu]. And the one who follows him to the gathering place [mahsharihi] is his deed ['amaluhu]."
Vol3 book 6a
Indeed, preoccupation [alhākum] with rivalry in worldly increase [at-takāthur] distracts you. The son of Adam says, "My wealth, my wealth!" But do you possess anything of your wealth except what you have eaten and thus consumed, or what you have worn and thus worn out, or what you have given in charity and thus preserved?

a.ihya:
Ihya 'Ulum al-Din Commentary

Vol4 book2
Indeed, among the people is he for whom the gaze of consideration [nazar al-i'tibar] is made easy, so he looks upon nothing from the world of dominion ['alam al-mulk] except that he crosses over with it to the world of sovereignty ['alam al-malakut], and his crossing is called a lesson ['ibrah]. And the Truth [al-Haqq] has commanded this, saying: "So take lesson, O you who possess insight." And among them is he whose inner sight [basirah] is blinded, so he does not take lesson, and thus he is confined within the world of dominion and the visible realm ['alam al-shahadah]. And the gates of Hell will be opened to his confinement, and this confinement is filled with a fire whose nature is to rise over the hearts [af'idah], except that between him and the perception of its pain is a veil [hijab]. So when that veil is lifted by death, he perceives. And concerning this, God, Exalted is He, manifested the Truth upon the tongue of a people whom He caused to speak with the Truth, and they said: "Paradise and the Fire are created, but the Blaze [al-Jahim] is perceived once by a perception called the knowledge of certainty ['ilm al-yaqin], and once by another perception called the eye of certainty ['ayn al-yaqin]. And the eye of certainty is not except in the Hereafter [al-Akhirah], and the knowledge of certainty can be in the world [al-dunya], but only for those who have fulfilled their portion from the light of certainty [nur al-yaqin]." Therefore, God, Exalted is He, said: "No! If you but knew with the knowledge of certainty, you would surely see the Blaze"—meaning, in the world—"Then you would surely see it with the eye of certainty"—meaning, in the Hereafter.

a.g: You will surely see the Hellfire.
Then you will surely see it with the eye of certainty.

a.g: Then you will surely be asked that Day about pleasure.
